column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Fort William
#Text=Fort William is a town in the Scottish Highlands , sitting at the head of Loch Linnhe .
#Text=With a population of 10,500 , it 's the main transport , commercial and visitor hub for the area .
#Text=It 's a major centre for outdoor activities , particularly hill-walking on Ben Nevis and skiing on the Nevis Range .
#Text=The TIC is Fort William iCentre at 15 High St , open daily 09:00-17:00.
#Text=A couple of miles north of town is a secondary built-up area at the point where Loch Linnhe turns west into Loch Eil , the River Lochy flows out , and the Caledonian Canal begins .
#Text=Facilities in these villages of Corpach , Bannavie , Caol and Inverlochy are also described on this page .
#Text=Loch Linnhe is a fjord , the sea-flooded southwest end of the Great Glen , the long diagonal fault line that slices across the Highlands to Inverness .
#Text=Inland along the glen are the freshwater lochs of Loch Lochy , Loch Oich and Loch Ness .
#Text=By plane
#Text=Inverness Airport is closer , but since you 'll need to hire a car anyway , fly to Glasgow GLA for its better choice of flights and fares .
#Text=Turn west onto M8 and cross the Erskine bridge to join A82 northwards past Loch Lomond ; maybe 2 hours 30 min to drive .
#Text=By train
#Text=Fort William has trains from Glasgow Queen Street via Arrochar ( for Loch Lomond ) , Crianlarich and Spean Bridge .
#Text=( These trains split at Crianlarich , with part of them going to Oban , so you need to be in the right section . )
#Text=There are four trains Mon - Sat and one on Sunday , taking four hours .
#Text=They continue west on the scenic West Highland Railway to Glenfinnan , Arisaig and Mallaig .
#Text=The Caledonian Sleeper runs overnight ( not Sat ) from London Euston , leaving around 21:00 to arrive in Fort William by 10:00 .
#Text=The southbound sleeper leaves Fort William at 19:50 to reach Euston by 08:00 .
#Text=A one-way sleeper berth costs from £200 , a seat-only from £80 , cheaper low season advance fares are sometimes available .
#Text=Alternatively take the Lowland Sleeper from Euston near midnight to arrive Glasgow Queen Street at 07:20 , then the 08:20 for Fort William ( arrives midday ) and Mallaig .
#Text=Coming back by that route you need to be on the 17:30 from Fort William to Queen Street , arriving 21:30 and waiting two hours for the southbound sleeper , reaching Euston by 07:00 .

#Text=The online booking system should generate a reservation for a particular berth or seat : if it does n't , phone up Caledonian Sleeper and ensure one , else you might be bumped off the train even if you 're holding a ticket for that specific date .
#Text=New sleeping coaches were expected to come into service by May 2019 , but by July were still awaited , with no starting date confirmed .
#Text=There 's no railway along the Great Glen between Fort William and Inverness , or south to Oban , take the bus .
#Text=By bus
#Text=Citylink buses 914 / 915 / 916 run four times daily from Glasgow Buchanan Street to Fort William , taking 3 hours .
#Text=Two of them continue via Spean Bridge and Laggan to Portree on Skye .
#Text=Citylink Bus 918 runs twice a day ( not Sunday ) to Oban , 90 mins .

#Text=Bus 919 runs along the Great Glen past Loch Ness to Inverness via Spean Bridge , Fort Augustus , Urquhart Castle and Drumnadrochit ; there are six Mon - Sat and two on Sunday , taking two hours .
#Text=Between Fort William and Mallaig , Shiel Bus 500 runs four times a day M - F , once on Saturday and Sunday , 90 mins .
#Text=Sit on the right for views of Glenfinnan Viaduct .
#Text=Shiel Buses also connect the small villages of Kilchoan , Acharacle , Lochaline and Strontian on the Arnamurchan peninsula .
#Text=These are timed for the school / shopping run , with just one bus ( M - Sa ) in the morning coming into Fort William , and one bus going back in the afternoon ; see Strontian for details .
#Text=Shiel Bus N44 runs six times a day ( M - F ) to Corran ferry pier , Ballachulish , Glencoe and Kinlochleven .
#Text=Get around
#Text=The centre of Fort William is small enough to get around on foot .
#Text=Shiel Bus N41 runs between Fort William and Roy Bridge , via Torlundy , Nevis Range Ski Centre and Spean Bridge .
#Text=It runs 7 times a day M-Sat .
#Text=Twice a day ( at around 09:00 and 17:00 ) year round , it extends from Fort William to Glen Nevis Youth Hostel .
#Text=May to Oct it 's supplemented by Bus N42 , which run 6 times daily to the Youth Hostel , with three buses extending to the Lower Falls .
#Text=Bike is ideal for exploring along the glens and Caledonian Canal .
#Text=Off Beat Bikes on High St ( daily 09:30 - 17:30 ) do hires and repairs and can suggest trails .
#Text=Scottish Highland Tours , ☏ +441397704901 .
#Text=Offers tours from Fort William in luxury buses , and taxis and cars from Fort William .
#Text=Greyhound Taxis , 131 Blar Mhor Rd Caol , ☏ +441397705050 .
#Text=A family-run taxi company , they cater to bikers , hill-walkers , or day trippers who do n't know their way around .
#Text=They have bike racks and ski racks , and a secure luggage trailer can be provided .
#Text=They operate 4- & 6-seater cabs .
#Text=See
#Text=Pleasant views across Loch Linnhe , the old Fort is just a few courses of masonry in a seaside park .
#Text=The town centre is Victorian , but has suffered from poor modern planning , with the busy A82 cutting it off from the prom .
#Text=West Highland Museum , Cameron Square , PH33 6AJ ( just off High Street ) .
#Text=Jan-Apr & Oct-Dec M - Sa 10:00 - 16:00 , May-Sept to 17:00 ; July Aug also Su 11:00-15:00. Regional history from earliest times through Jacobites and Victorians to the present .
#Text=Free , but donations requested .

#Text=The Caledonian Canal is a coast-to-coast channel , built by Thomas Telford in the early 19th C , that makes use of the string of lochs and rivers along the Great Glen - it 's 60 miles long but only 22 miles are man-made .

#Text=Commercially and strategically it was obsolete as soon as it was completed in 1822 , as shipping had outgrown it , and round-the-coast navigation was much safer since the end of the Napoleonic wars .
#Text=It fell into disrepair but was rehabilitated for pleasure craft .
#Text=At the south end , it starts from Loch Linnhe by a short ladder of locks at Corpach near Fort William .
#Text=A mile east at Banavie is the photogenic Neptune 's Staircase , Banavie PH33 7NG .
#Text=This is a ladder of eight locks , great for photos , but a long afternoon 's work to navigate .
#Text=It then runs to Lock Lochy , to ascend further at Laggan at the other end .
#Text=( So yes , these could be called the Loch Lochy locks , which , when locked . . . )
#Text=Another straight run connects Loch Oich , the highest part of the system .
#Text=( Higher still , Loch Garry feeds water to the canal via the River Garry , but the river is n't navigable . )
#Text=From Loch Oich the canal continues north , descending by another ladder of locks into Loch Ness .
#Text=Loch Ness is the magnificent natural channel at the heart of the canal system .
#Text=At its north end , canal and River Ness flow down from Dochgarroch Weir towards the sea at Inverness .
#Text=Lochaber Geopark in High St ( M - Sa 10:00 - 16:00 ) promotes awareness and organises trips and study around the region 's weird geology .

#Text=This played a key role in shaping 19th / 20th C understanding of how the world 's landscapes were constructed - it was realised that the Caledonian Mountains once stretched through Svalbard and Greenland into the Appalachians , until sundered by the new Atlantic Ocean .
#Text=The geopark stretches from Rannoch Moor in the south to Glen Garry in the north , and from Loch Laggan in the east to the Small Isles out west .
#Text=For instance 20 miles away are the " Roads of Glen Roy " : this glen above the Spean valley has three long parallel ledges on the hillside that look man-made .
#Text=They were in fact cut by ice grinding along the shore of a vanished lake , which lay at different levels during a cold period after the last Ice Age when arctic conditions returned .
#Text=Treasures of the Earth is a geology museum and shop at Corpach PH33 7JL .
#Text=Collection of crystals , gemstones and fossils .
#Text=Open daily Nov-Feb 10:00 - 16:00 ; Mar-June & Sept Oct to 17:00 , July Aug to 18:00 , adult £5 .
